statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: New Mexico 91, Alcorn State 59
article.story: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) -- Guard J.R. Giddens in street clothes on game night should be a bad thing for New Mexico. But not in the first round of the Lobo Invitational. With its leading scorer on the bench nursing a sprained left ankle, New Mexico had no trouble beating Alcorn State 91-59 Thursday on the first night of the Lobos' annual holiday tournament. Tony Danridge scored a career-high 24 points to more than make up for Giddens' missing 17.5 scoring average. "My teammates found me wide open. They made great passes and I made a couple of shots," said Danridge, whose previous scoring high was 17 points. Danridge actually hit 8 of 13 shots and was 7-for-8 on free throws. New Mexico (10-3) won for the fifth time in the last six games and never missed Giddens, who got hurt in the Lobos' 71-68 win over then-No. 8 Wichita State last week in Las Vegas, Nev. The Lobos never trailed against the Braves (1-9), whose only win this season was against Paul Quinn three weeks ago. Guard Delvin Thompson led the Braves with 17 points and Jarvis Williams scored 14. Thompson also had 8 of the Braves' 17 turnovers. Alcorn State stayed close in the first half but could not sustain its offense in the second half, hitting just 8 of 30 shots (26.7 percent). Asked what his team gained from its latest lopsided loss, Alcorn State coach Sam West said, "I take the first half. We played good in the first half with the exception of a couple of turnovers." The Lobo Invitational, which started in 1965, is the nation's fifth oldest in-season tournament and New Mexico has enjoyed considerable success in it. The Lobos are 71-12 overall in the tournament and have won it 29 times. Much of the Lobos' success can be attributed to less than stellar fields in the tournament and this year is no different. Besides Alcorn State, the two other invited teams are Pepperdine, which came in with a 3-10 record, and Binghamton (6-4), which is in only its sixth season as a Division I-A program. Some of New Mexico's recent first round opponents in the tournament included Dartmouth, Mississippi Valley State, Northwestern State and Portland State. Danridge scored 15 points and hit 7 of 10 shots in the first half. The Lobos led 42-33 at the break, then broke it open early in the second half, when the Braves failed to score a field goal in the first four minutes. Center Aaron Johnson, who did not start, scored 18 points for New Mexico, 13 of them in the second half. Chad Toppert scored 11 points and had 3 of the Lobos' 10 3-pointers. New Mexico moves up in competition after this weekend, with Bob Knight and Texas Tech awaiting the Lobos for a game in Lubbock on Monday. Some of the Lobos were already looking ahead. "It builds momentum," Danridge said of the win over Alcorn State. "We're about to go into conference and we've got a big game against Texas Tech."
